awd_titl_txt: Catch Bond Clusters in Cell Adhesion (using DNA Origami)
awd_abstract_narration:
Cells interact and respond to their surroundings, and the adhesion - or contact force - between cells and their surroundings is an important feature of this interaction.  This adhesion is the result of surface receptors on the cells called integrins.  In tissues and organs, cellular adhesion plays a role in normal and abnormal physiology.  As a result, cell adhesion is likely to play a role in disease processes such as cancer, infection, inflammation, and blood clotting.  If cell adhesion can be understood, and subsequently controlled, it may lead to new insights into biotechnology or treatment strategies.  While previous research has focused on a single bond, or connection, between a cell and its surrounding, it is known that it is actually a cluster of these bonds that governs cellular adhesion.  This project seeks to develop a fundamental understanding of how the size and shape of clusters of bonds affect the strength and behavior of the adhesion.  A combination of experiments, using a novel approach called DNA origami, and computational modeling will be used to address these fundamental questions.  In addition, the project seeks to expand interest in STEM and an understanding of how engineers can support their communities through a series of K12 outreach activities as well as by integrating the research focus and outreach activities into undergraduate engineering coursework.

This project will use the bond between platelet glycoprotein Ib (GPIb) and the blood protein von Willebrand Factor (VWF), both of which are involved in blood clotting, as a model system to study the behavior of clusters of catch bonds.  It is hypothesized that the strength of the bonds between GPIb and a specific region of VWF will vary significantly based on the size and geometry of the clusters, which allows a single molecular bond to perform a range of functions based on these variations.  DNA origami, which can control the attachment of molecules in specific quantities and locations, will be used to experimentally investigate this hypothesis.  This novel method will be combined with measurements of adhesion force using atomic force microscopy and the development of computer simulations.  Three aims have been established: 1) to determine whether clusters of molecular bonds have catch, slip, or ideal behavior; 2) to determine how clusters of these bonds contribute to shear-enhanced rolling adhesion in VWF; and 3) to determine how clusters of these bonds contribute to stable platelet adhesion.  Thus, the integrated modeling and experimental approach will provide key insights into both fundamental cellular adhesion biomechanics along with these processes in a specific physiological process, blood clotting.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Civil, Mechanical, and Manufacturing Innovation

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual merit: 

The goal of this project was to better understand the mechanical strength of cell adhesion during blood clotting, immunity, infection, and other processes important to biology and human health. Specifically, sought to determine how cell adhesion reflects the clustering, or organization, of multiple adhesive molecules.  Many adhesive molecules have evolved to form “catch bonds” that are activated by tension during adhesion to provide better regulation of adhesion. 

Remarkably, we showed that clusters of catch bonds can display either catch behavior, in which tension makes the cell bind better, or slip behavior in which tension detaches the cell, with the latter behavior occurring when there are more or softer individual adhesive interactions making up the cell adhesive material. Consistent with this, we learned that immune cells called monocytes became softer and adhered more weakly during an inflammatory cell death called pyroptosis.  

We also improved the methods that are especially critical for measuring these types of cell adhesive interactions. We improved on “magnetic tweezers” that subject bond clusters to a constant tensile force using magnets. We also improved on methods to measure the traction force of single cells, developing a method we call “black dots” that patterns the surface to allow easy calculation of microscale stretch patterns - and thus forces - on this surface during cell adhesion.  

We also learned that clusters of short-lived bonds exposed to a shearing force parallel to the surface can allow stable cell adhesion, because the bond clusters can creep slowly over a surface in the direction of force while individual bonds break, the remaining bonds stretch just a little, and the broken bonds reform in a slightly different position. Remarkably, the clusters creep most slowly at a level of traction force that applies just enough tension to activate but not overpower the individual catch bonds. This explains why platelets bound to surfaces can spread and apply traction forces when bound only through short-lived catch bonds. We also found that creeping was much slower for larger clusters. Consistent with this, we found that uniform distribution of adhesive proteins and the cell cytoskeleton into one large cluster correlated with higher traction forces in platelets.  

Broader impacts:  

The project supported the development of the Husky Adapt program into a sustainable student organization. This program trains undergraduate students to introduce underrepresented high school students to “Toy Adaptation,” which is the process of adapting toys to be usable by children with disabilities, by wiring a toy chosen by or for a specific child to a customized device that accommodate that child’s disabilities to allow they to play with the toy. Importantly, this program teaches the high school and undergraduate students the basic principles of inclusive design, which involves consideration of the unique needs of individuals or communities who may benefit from the design.  We learned that this approach contributes to the recruitment and training of diverse students in engineering.

This project also contributed to the training of ten undergraduate students, eight of whom are from groups traditionally underrepresented in the STEM fields, in the use of computational simulations and/or experiments of cell or molecular adhesion. 

The project also contributed to the curriculum in the Departments of Bioengineering and Mechanical Engineering at the University of Washington. We introduced DNA origami to an upper level elective for mechanical engineering students called “Biological Frameworks”. We added toy adaptation to the electrical circuits lab of a first-year Department of Engineering multi-departmental collaborative course titled “Engineering Transformation of Health.” Finally, we embarked on a multi-year process to introduce more diversity, equity, and inclusion (DEI) skills into the Bioengineering core curriculum. We learned that students experiencing DEI skills in the curriculum felt prepared to contribute to or even lead diverse and inclusive work environments independent of their own identities, but that the material and training provided did not eliminate identity-related disparities in student experiences of inclusivity.

Our broader impacts were disseminated to the field of higher education through conference presentations and publications on the methods and impact of both toy adaptation and DEI in the curriculum


Last Modified: 01/04/2024
Modified by: Wendy E Thomas
